p: In order to minimize the high resistance for ion transport at the polymer/ceramic electrolyte interface, the barriers for Li ions migration across the interfaces between polymers and ceramics can be greatly reduced by modifying the ceramics. Chinnam and Wunder 120 developed a feasible solution to address this issue. The inorganic lithium ion‐conducting glass ceramics (LICGCs) Li 2O‐Al 2O 3‐SiO 2‐P 2O 5‐TiO 2‐GeO 2 were sputter‐coated with a 200 nm thick SiO 2 layer and then silanated with CH 3O(CH 2CH 2O) x(CH 2) 3Si(OCH 2CH 3) 3 (PEG‐silane) in the presence of LiTFSI (Figure 11c). After silanization, the PEG‐silane/LiTFSI shows superior contact with SiO 2‐LICGCs, which provide crucial lithium ion‐conducting channels to considerably decrease the interfacial resistance. In addition, the ball milling at low velocity and temperature is a simple and low‐cost way to facilitate the uniform dispersion of ceramic fillers in polymer host and construct more efficient interface between ceramic and polymer. 74, 121, 122
